This keeps failing in recent builds, not only on Linux, but also on the Mac. Do you know if the Mac uses a Java 5 VM too?

Or is it "just" a performance issue that causes this?

According to Sonia only the JDT tests run on 1.5 on the Mac.  It's odd though - you don't usually see timeouts on addition - the code to check for that is fairly straightforward.  You typically see dynamic failures on removal.
Note: Despite having not done anything to cause it, I am currently running on Java5 by default on the Mac. Steve, who also claims to have done nothing is running on 1.4.2.
Wow, interesting - I too am running 1.5 and this is on a clean (5 day old) Tiger install.

If (for whatever reason) the processing of the add or remove event took a long time, we only checked whether we timed out and did not check whether the add or removal actually worked. I changed the asserts to check that the adds/removes were processed properly instead of just checking for the timeout case.

Fix released to HEAD >20060629.

This test seems to fail intermittently.  #testActionSets and #testActionSetPartAssociations also seem to be failing on a fairly regular basis.   When I run the entire suite I found an OutOfMemoryError being reported to the console.  I think all these tests are failing (at least in the 3.2.1 stream) because of the DataTransfer suite (which is run before the DynamicPlugins suite), as instance variables of classes in this suite are not nulled in doTearDown().  When I run the DynamicPlugins suite on its own, all tests pass.  When I move the DataTransfer suite to the end of the UI test suite, then an out of memory error occurs in that suite.  After I changed the code in the DataTransfer suite to null out instance variables at the end of each test, no more failures occured in the suite.  I will attach the patch.

Created an attachment (id=49768)
apply patch to org.eclipse.ui.tests

I also have to null out an instance variable in DynamicTestCase#doTearDown to get the tests to pass. 
Patch plus above mentioned change released to 3.2.1 and HEAD streams.
This hasn't appeared in awhile now.  Marking as verfied in I20061031-0656
